image.altText: Donald Trump (left) in a white shirt and black jacket. A blonde smiling woman (right) wearing sunglasses and brown jacket.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Judge dismisses Donald Trump's defamation claim against E. Jean Carroll — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A federal judge in the US has tossed out former president Donald Trump's countersuit against writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a $US5 million ($7.6 million) sex abuse lawsuit against him in May. The judge ruled that Trump can't claim Carroll defamed him by continuing to say she was not only sexually abused but raped. Trump attorney Alina Habba says Trump's lawyers will appeal "the flawed decision" to dismiss his counterclaim. Carroll is also pursuing her own defamation suit against Trump. Her lawyer, Robbie Kaplan, says Carroll is pleased with the ruling and looking ahead to a trial scheduled in January in her defamation suit, which concerns a series of remarks that Trump has made in denying her sexual assault allegation. Carroll accuses Trump of trapping her in a luxury department store dressing room in 1996, where the alleged incident occurred. Trump denies any of it happened, and even that they ran into each other at the store. He has accused her of inventing "a fraudulent and false story" to sell a memoir.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Judge dismisses Donald Trump's defamation suit against E. Jean Carroll, who he was found to have sexually abused

props.alt: Donald Trump in a suit and tie holding an umbrella in the rain next to a car

children.content: (AP: Alex Brandon)
A federal judge in the US has tossed out former president Donald Trump's countersuit against writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a $US5 million ($7.6 million) sex abuse lawsuit against him in May.
The judge ruled that Trump can't claim Carroll defamed him by continuing to say she was not only sexually abused but raped.
Trump attorney Alina Habba says Trump's lawyers will appeal "the flawed decision" to dismiss his counterclaim.
Carroll is also pursuing her own defamation suit against Trump.

Her lawyer, Robbie Kaplan, says Carroll is pleased with the ruling and looking ahead to a trial scheduled in January in her defamation suit, which concerns a series of remarks that Trump has made in denying her sexual assault allegation.
Carroll accuses Trump of trapping her in a luxury department store dressing room in 1996
, where the alleged incident occurred.
Trump denies any of it happened, and even that they ran into each other at the store. He has accused her of inventing "a fraudulent and false story" to sell a memoir.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An investigation into the weekend's fatal house fire on Brisbane's bayside is trying to establish whether there were working smoke alarms at the property. Wayne Godinet, 34, and his five young sons died in the early morning blaze on Russell Island on Sunday. The boys' mother, Samantha Stephenson, and another woman survived the fire. Queensland Fire and Emergency Services Commissioner Greg Leach says by law, the home should have been fitted with at least one hard-wired smoke alarm. "Hopefully we can determine that either by finding remains of a smoke alarm site, although as I said it's been a very hot fire or we might be able to track through council records whether it was compliant at the time it was moved there," he said. The cause of the fire is being investigated, with police saying yesterday they were keeping an open mind about whether or not it was suspicious.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investigators contiue to comb scene of Russell Island fire tragedy

children.content: An investigation into the weekend's fatal house fire on Brisbane's bayside is trying to establish whether there were working smoke alarms at the property.
Wayne Godinet, 34, and his five young sons died in the early morning blaze on Russell Island on Sunday.
The boys' mother, Samantha Stephenson, and another woman survived the fire.
Queensland Fire and Emergency Services Commissioner Greg Leach says by law, the home should have been fitted with at least one hard-wired smoke alarm.

"Hopefully we can determine that either by finding remains of a smoke alarm site, although as I said it's been a very hot fire or we might be able to track through council records whether it was compliant at the time it was moved there," he said.
The cause of the fire is being investigated, with police saying yesterday they were keeping an open mind about whether or not it was suspicious.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The final police officer to face court for his role in killing George Floyd, Tou Thao, has been sentenced to four years and nine months in jail. Thao was convicted for holding back concerned bystanders who gathered as former officer Derek Chauvin knelt on Mr Floyd's neck for more than nine minutes while the Black man pleaded for his life. Thao previously testified he merely served as a "human traffic cone" during the May 25, 2020 incident. Thao spoke at length about his Christian growth during his 340 days behind bars but denied any responsibility for Mr Floyd's death during his sentencing hearing. Mr Floyd's death and cries of "I can't breathe" set off protests worldwide against police brutality and racism. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Final Minneapolis police officer sentenced over George Floyd murder

featuredLink.title: Final police officer sentenced over George Floyd murder
